Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The Mother Superior has asked the nun to lead a series of daily reflections for the entire community during an upcoming retreat.
Story: I sat at my desk, the weight of the day pressing on my shoulders. As a lawyer, I was used to the strict boundaries of confidentiality, the sacred trust between client and counsel. Today, an assistant—new and eager—asked for access to files she didn’t need, just to make her work easier. I knew the rules, the lines I could not cross, but her hopeful eyes made me hesitate. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from the convent: Mother Superior wanted me to lead daily reflections for the retreat. It was an honor, but it meant hours of preparation, deep spiritual study, and presence with my sisters. I felt torn. The law demanded my vigilance and discretion; my faith called for my time and contemplation. Both roles expected my full devotion, but I was only one person. My mind raced, heart heavy, as I tried to reconcile the demands of justice and the call to spiritual leadership, knowing I could not give both what they deserved.
